Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Genomic architecture as a species delimitation tool: validating a novel approach using rDNA variation for discovering species boundaries in ground beetles.
Award.AbstractNarration:
With millions of undiscovered or undescribed species estimated, new techniques that increase scientists' ability to discover species is urgently needed. Recognizing biodiversity is important not only for comparative biology, but also because it provides an important decision-making framework for very diverse applied disciplines related to biology, such as agriculture, bioremediation, biophysics, biomedicine (among others). This research proposes to develop a new, widely applicable approach to identifying species using ground beetles (genus Bembidion) as a model. Preliminary data show that species in this group can have large differences in some aspects of the structure of their genomes despite being very closely related. These differences in genome structure are revealed by examining a set of genes (ribosomal DNA (rDNA) genes) with modern sequencing techniques. This analysis of 'rDNA fingerprints' costs little to obtain and has potential to help discover new species more efficiently than more traditionally used methods. Results from this research will be used for training opportunities for undergraduate students, as well as a community outreach project involving high school students.

The use of rDNA fingerprints as a species delimitation tool will be validated by profiling additional specimens through low-coverage Illumina sequencing and comparing patterns in rDNA fingerprints to existing species concepts that are built on five gene trees and morphological analysis. The extent of variation in rDNA fingerprints across a wider group of carabid beetles will be explored using a real-time PCR assay followed by additional sequencing of relevant specimens. Finally, the mechanism of copy number inflation within the rDNA cistron will be explored through comparative fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), to test the hypothesis that many copies of fragments of rDNA have been transferred to heterochromatic DNA near its boundary with euchromatin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific Merit

The overall structure and organization of genomes holds layers of information informative to studies on evolution. However, studying the entire architecture (i.e., structure and organization) of genomes can be prohibitively expensive. We investigated whether copy number variation profiles of ribosomal genes (a set of genes critical to cellular function in all organisms other than bacteria and archaeans) can serve as a simple measure of variation in a component of the genome that might correlate with more complex biological phenomena. We found notable variation in ribosomal DNA profiles that strongly correlates with species boundaries and provides evidence of rapid genome evolution among closely related species that is not apparent from studying traditional sources of data. Our findings suggest this simple measure may be a useful tool in studies that seek to define boundaries among closely related species. In addition, our findings suggest that using copy number proiles of ribosomal DNA, or other repetitive DNA sequences, could be a useful tool to visualize patterns of genome evolution in groups with few genomic resources. 

Broader impacts

This project led to the culmination of Co-PI Sproul's dissertation research, and facilitated its successful defense. Findings from this project directly led to Co-PI Sproul's submission and successful funding of a post-doctoral fellowship proposal. In addition to building upon the findings of this project, the postdoctoral fellowship has a primary goal of increasing participation of underrepresented groups in science, which includes outreach and deep mentorship of students in minority majority high-schools and undergraduates from underrepresented groups. Since starting that fellowship, the interdisciplinary skills acquired during this project have already facilitated new collaborations and research opportunities that would have not been likely without the experienced and expanded interests that Co-PI Sproul gained during this project. In addition, Co-PI Sproul has gained valuable experience preparing research for submission to a high-profile journal (i.e., Procedings of the National Academy of Sciences), opportunities to share research at national conferences and an invited seminar at the University of Rochester, and valuable mentoring experience throughout the project. This project has led directly to two additional manuscripts currently in the early stages of preparation, and has become a platform that will continue shaping his research identity in coming years.

In addition, the career development of two undergraduate students has been impacted through mentorship under this project. Both students gained new experience in technical laboratory procedures and data analysis. One student successfully designed and defended an honor's thesis built around contributions to this project, and contributed as a coauthor to a manuscript recently submitted for publication. The experience gained during this project facilitated her transition to a technical position in a cancer research laboratory. The other student mentored under this project plans to apply to graduate school in biology.
